name: Starfield
reviews:
unplayable on my PC even with all the settings at the lowest. My PC can run Fallout 4 but not this. This is such a disaster. Wish I didn't spend more than 2 hours trying to get it to work, then I could have gotten a refund. [h1]Skyrim vibes with added space travel![/h1]
This game is [u]a lot[/u] better than I would have given it credit for, and I'm honestly enjoying myself quite a bit. Now, don't get me wrong here: I'll be the first to state that this definitely isn't a perfect game or such. Heck, I've already experienced a few glitches myself.

Thing is... games don't have to be perfect in order to be perceived as such.

[b]Maybe too high expectations?[/b]

Each to their own (!) but I think that one of the issues with people not enjoying this game is setting your expectations too high. See, this [i]isn't[/i] "Skyrim in space"; space travel is simply an added game mechanic which exists within the way you normally play most Bethesda games.

So... no, you can't use your spaceship to sour over the surface of a planet in order to map out the location of most structures. Nor can you decide where you're going to land your ship. All of that is a bit static. However... the game does compensate for all that, because once you discovered a location on a planet you can tell the game to go there after which you won't have to go through the whole routine of landing and walking again.

And honestly?  I like it this way. Despite the fact that I already discovered quite a few locations I still more than often just refuse to fast travel and instead get into my spaceship, close the door(s), take a seat in the cockpit and then I take off. Only to do the test of the navigation once I'm in orbit. I even perform a (semi-) manual jump into the next system.

No, I'm [i]not[/i] "wasting my time", I'm roleplaying. Ever heard of it?

[h2]This game is [u]massive[/u][/h2]
There are a lot of NPC's for you to meet and missions for you to complete, and I really love it. Sometimes small, sometimes silly and sometimes you also need to make a bit of your own fun. And what I love the most here is that not everything gets presented to you or is made obvious.

For example...  early on in the game you'll discover the city of New Atlantis and [u]a lot[/u] of of the game will be done here or from here. Plenty of missions for you to pick up. And it seems like the perfect playing map... huge city, citizens everywhere and plenty of NPC's to talk with. Dare I say that the layout even gives me "Kotor" and "Mass Effect" vibes?

So [i[then[/i] I wondered... ey... the game also talks about vegetation, fauna and minerals ("resources").  Is there more to all this than the game is showing me?  So I decided to hop over a fence, slide my way down and... oh dear: all of a sudden I'm in a whole new (dangerous!) part of the world. And I'm [b]loving[/b] every moment of it. I even met other NPC's which got me laughing quite a bit: "[spoiler]I'm sorry, can't you see I'm busy dying?  ugh... [/spoiler]", and sure enough; that's exactly what happened (not by my doing btw!).

Experiences like these make me convinced that sometimes... it's also what you make of things. And this game puts plenty of attention into detail.

[b]Destructive tools are also weapons![/b]

I've seen this so many times: you have this powerful tool which is strong enough to tear through rocks, but as soon as you point it to some hostile creature then... "of course" it doesn't work, why would it? This isn't a weapon you silly player!

Starfield does that "a little" different and I was quite surprised when I discovered it. To me it simply adds up to the complexity and vastness of this game.

No, like I said before it isn't perfect...  but I'm sure am having a lot of fun so far!

[b]Get the editor too![/b]

Starfield, just like Skyrim before it, is a game that runs on its own so called "game engine". Studios often rely on such 'engines' to help them separate between the process of game design and actual game development. For example.... say I want to add a new datapack ("note")... thanks to the engine I don't have to worry about adding the right textures or having to make my own opening effects: all of that is something the engine can handle for me. [i]So..[/i] I just tell it that I want to add a new datapack ("Book" / "DataSlate") and the engine will handle all the details like the way it looks, how it'll sound when I pick it up, whether I can actually pick it up or not, etc. All I have to do is select what I want to use, add the text I want to add and eventually I also need to place this new item somewhere in the world.

No coding, no making new graphics, just design.  And that's what [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2722710/Starfield_Creation_Kit/]the Starfield creation kit[/url] can help you with. If you're going to play Starfield then I highly suggest that you also pick up the editor. Heck... if you're stuck in a mission... you [i]could[/i] consider to check it out in the editor to see what you might be missing. 

[h1]In conclusion...[/h1]
Look, if you were expecting a whole new game with lots of different new mechanics and such.. maybe even secretly hoping for an actual spacesim (?) then sorry to say but you may end up disappointed. But if you can enjoy the idea of being able to travel through space and visit all sorts of strange planets and explore weird locations, meet new NPC's and such then you might be in for a treat.

The world is pretty big, and there's [u]a lot[/u] of stuff to discover & do, plenty to keep you busy for dozens of hours to come. The voice acting is very well done I think and although some characters look a bit weird... look, didn't we say the exact same thing for those in Tamriel?  Here I was thinking that elves would be the most beautiful beings in the world, not some bizarre looking hags.

Yes, there are loading screens and yes: your spaceship only gets used when you're actually out in space (so: in orbit), as soon as you're on a planet it basically becomes your (static) base of operations. Extra storage space to take with you wherever you go! ;)

But the vibes of old are all here...  exploring a planet, using your scanner and seeing "unknown" somewhere in the distance?  Let's go check it out!  Oh wait, there's another one!  Being able to find new loot, upgrade and customize your stuff, meet up with new friends (and enemies) ...

Each to their own, but I'm having a great time with this game, and can definitely recommend it because of that.
 What a waste.
short_description: Starfield is the first new universe in 25 years from Bethesda Game Studios, the award-winning creators of The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim and Fallout 4.

name: PAYDAY 2
reviews:
Dopamine check Came for the soundtrack, stayed for the surprisingly fun gameplay.

Kinda BS how so much was licensed content though Payday 2 is the greatest and certainly the final good game in the Payday series. It's essentially just an extension of the first game, however the gameplay is so captivating that it's very difficult to just not sink into a "two-week phase" when you truly start playing this game. I wish Starbreeze would actually try and build off the success from this game, rather than just wing it with the abomination of a creation that rests in Payday 3.

My suggestion to people who are interested in playing Payday for the first time: Buy this game! It is unbelievably better than the first and third installments, and is by far the most entertaining cops and robbers game I've ever played with friends, matching the likes of GTA heists such as Diamond Casino and Cayo Perico.
short_description: PAYDAY 2 is an action-packed, four-player co-op shooter that once again lets gamers don the masks of the original PAYDAY crew - Dallas, Hoxton, Wolf and Chains - as they descend on Washington DC for an epic crime spree.

name: Life is Strange: Before the Storm
reviews:
Before the Storm may not be as strong as the original Life Is Strange in terms of gameplay or plot twists, but emotionally, it still works.

This prequel focuses less on choices and more on understanding Chloe's anger, her loneliness, and the way she clings to people when sheâ€™s afraid of losing them.

The three episodes felt short (plus episode Farewell if you buy DLC), but meaningful and yet still worked on me.

If the first Life Is Strange is about dealing with consequences, Before the Storm is about the pain that comes before them. Nobody ever reads my reviews, but i just wanna give this a thumbs up. There is no Turkish language in the game.
short_description: Life is Strange: Before the Storm is a new three part standalone story adventure set three years before the events of the first game. This time play as Chloe Price, a rebel who forms an unlikely friendship with Rachel Amber in a dramatic new story in the BAFTA award winning franchise.

short_description: Wreckfest is a demolition derby themed racing game with soft-body damage modeling, sophisticated driving dynamics and in-depth vehicle upgrading, featuring both demolition derbies and more traditional track races. Itâ€™s all about fun, breakneck racing and over-the-top crashes.

name: theHunter: Call of the Wildâ„¢
reviews:
fun WONDERFUL, This is the only game I have played that you can walk through a tree stump but not a small bush. Shoot through a tree to hit an animal but not a small bush. Crawl through a small bush to ambush something just to get eaten by a wolf. Have animals get stuck on a pebble while also being able to scale the side of a mountain at crazy speeds. 

All jokes aside, this is a fun game. Learning how skills and perks work together, and learning how to track an animal properly is interesting. The mechanics and how herd management works is awesome.

For the age of the game, the graphics are still stunning. I'll find myself just sitting at a lake watching nothing for minutes at a time.

The fact that the game is still being updated years after release is awesome as well. The devs are very interactive with the community and are always adding new stuff for us to mess with.

9/10 for sure.
short_description: Discover an atmospheric hunting game like no other in this realistic, stunning open world â€“ regularly updated in collaboration with the community. Immerse yourself in the single player campaign, or share the ultimate hunting experience with friends.

name: Tribes: Ascend
reviews:
I remember using the separate launcher away from Steam, and logging in so many hours into this game. It's a shell of its former self now, however, with the removal of classes, removed base upgrades, the credit equips, bizarre weapon rebalancing, and now the inability to make a new account. Despite the last bouts of updates, Hi-Rez seems to have already abandoned this game a while back to focus on their more recents projects like Smite and Paladins. One can only hope that either a new Tribes game or the upcoming title Midair can recapture that wonderful, extremely fast-paced action I experienced several years ago. Good game.
Shame its dead.

A bit underpopulated, but that can change if you get it too!

name: Total War: WARHAMMER II
reviews:
Total War: Warhammer II is more than just â€œanother chapterâ€. It feels more polished, better tuned, and deeper overall.

And yes, you can finally respec skill points if you made a mistake â€” which is a huge plus. really fun game to play, the only annoying part is the fac that you have to buy older titles and a bunch of dlc to balance the game but in general quite addictive and fun if you want to search for a game that you will invest hundreds of hours to master AMAZING GAME WORTH IT
short_description: Strategy gaming perfected. A breath-taking campaign of exploration, expansion and conquest across a fantasy world. Turn-based civilisation management and real-time epic strategy battles with thousands of troops and monsters at your command.

name: PC Building Simulator
reviews: Don't have $300+ dollars for RAM for that new build you had planned to buy parts for on Black Friday? Here's the next best thing! While the hardware included in this game shows it's age, it's actually a pretty decent practice tool for beginner builders like myself utilizing the Free Build mode. Gets you into the practice of installing parts in the proper order, and not forgetting that thermal paste. Interesting soundtrack... Very fun game I guess, However the RAM crisis isn't modeled yet Lasted about an hour before I uninstalled and refunded it because it started to feel like work instead of something fun and enjoyable.  The concept sounded neat, but 30 minutes in...you're juggling multiple jobs and using screenshots or a notepad to keep track of everything, you're told a machine needs a video card upgrade but doesn't tell you details so you waste money on parts that don't satisfy the upgrade requirement, customers give you hints about things they want that aren't part of the job and no details are given but you need to do it for better reviews to unlock more jobs, etc.  I got an in-game email about some sort of notepad type thing I could use on my "computer"...but it's tedious running back and forth between your workspace and your computer trying to remember what's what.  I'm sure once you grind a bunch of jobs and open up more workspace, while googling for hints, it's a lot easier...but I don't like feeling like I'm at work while I'm trying to play a game.  They were so close to having a really neat timekiller of a game, but it fell a bit short and ends up becoming a headache.
short_description: Build and grow your very own computer repair enterprise as you learn to diagnose, fix and build PCs. With real-world licensed components and comprehensive hardware and software simulation, you can plan and bring your ultimate PC to life.

name: Don't Starve
reviews: Just don't starve. good vibes very fun when you can stay alive.. LOL
short_description: Donâ€™t Starve is an uncompromising wilderness survival game full of science and magic. Enter a strange and unexplored world full of strange creatures, dangers, and surprises. Gather resources to craft items and structures that match your survival style.

name: Braid
reviews: this game was an amazing brain game that was realy hard and fun, and wasnt like stupidly easy like some other games, i also liked the art and music alot so that was nice, if your into combat or fast shooters this isnt for u, but if u are into slow hard brain games this is amazing! 8.9/10 A classic platformer. The superb anti-Mario platformer. Fall off a cliff. Restart level? Nope, just rewind. Boing on some legally-distinct goombas and enjoy surprisingly emotive lore. The princess is not in this castle.
short_description: This is the original version of Braid from 2009, which may not work well on newer systems. For an updated version of the game with nicer graphics, more levels and a large amount of developer commentary, see Braid, Anniversary Edition.

name: Factorio
reviews:
The gold standard for factory games.

Most of the challenge is in the 2D nature of the game. Other than short underground connections, you can't layer your logistics design. As more items join the production chain your base can quickly turn into spaghetti with conveyers everywhere.

What's most amazing is that when you win the game after 40 hours you'll feel compelled to play again and try to build a cleaner designed base. There's also plenty of challenging achievements for long time players.

If you're new to factory games, consider this a solid recommendation to start here. worth the pricetag. but it's a fairly steep learning curve so don't expect to hop in and find it easy. 
Though if you do like a game which requires a bit more thinking than clicking it's very rewarding I don't regret buying this game.
short_description: Factorio is a game about building and creating automated factories to produce items of increasing complexity, within an infinite 2D world. Use your imagination to design your factory, combine simple elements into ingenious structures, and finally protect it from the creatures who don't really like you.

name: Saints Row IV: Re-Elected
reviews:
Its very good game peak game. 10/10 worth coming back for the 3$ sale 6/10, it could have been much better.

It's not as good as Saints Row The Third (my all-time favorite), but it's still a lot of fun. I can spend hours hitting cars to earn money while listening to an alien reciting poetry with an annoying journalist, or blowing eardrums with a Polka Gun, or even killing the police with a dildo sword or riding a velociraptor.

As I said, it's not as good as its predecessor, it's a little better than the spin-off in hell, but it has many flaws. The biggest problems are that the game's narrative is uninteresting, being inside a simulation breaks the immersion a lot, and having to constantly use a stupid portal ruins the rhythm. Also, being the same city for about 4 games is too much.

Saints Row 3 has an incredibly functional escalating story with multiple epic endings, but this one has a bad and funny ending, with no real consequences. Everyone is dead, the city is a lie, Earth has been destroyed, and you're in a stasis pod. It's simple, small, weak, and depressing.

In terms of gameplay, the powers you use all the time ruin much of the "better than GTA" fun I had with the third game. This, coupled with the glitch effects that constantly remind you that everything is fake, also contributes to the feeling.

Perhaps if there were a way to go back in time and reclaim the planet before the invasion, with more realistic means of travel and combat, it could be really fun.

In the end, the feeling of fun while playing ends with a sense of lost potential when the game is over. Some side missions with altered gameplay mechanics are cool, but we lose the old excitement of the missions, like the old Genki, to give way to a confusing and uninspired superpower arena.
short_description: Experience the insane antics of Saints Row IV. The Saints have gone from the Penthouse to the White House - but Earth has been invaded and itâ€™s up to you to save it with an arsenal of superpowers and strange weapons, in the wildest open world game ever.

name: Deus Ex: Mankind Divided
reviews: This review will probably be my indulgence, as I didn't get the Tablet Collector achievement, and because of this, I tried to fix it with the Debug Menu for Deus Ex: Mankind Divided, but I accidentally knocked out all the achievements I didn't have yet. I clicked the wrong button, and I don't know if the "achievement hunter" gods will forgive me. At least I completed Breach with flying colors, and the rest of the Deus Ex games did too. It was frustrating that the controller scheme doesn't work properly. Can't zoom on one scheme, can't get any response from R3 on the others, etc. But I kept it and worked around it. Played 20 hours and was having enough fun that navigating the "world" and poor shop menuing issues were trivial. Then right around  20 hours, it stopped saving. So at the 21 hour mark when I died, I lost a lot of sidequest and story prog. No point continuing to play if it isn't going to save. Probably won't get a refund. Should of just returned it when I saw the controller issues. Oh well. Playing Deus Ex MD with Rudy END gfx mod in 2025 is a must! Otherwise, this is DE:MD. You know what it is. 5/5 stars.
short_description: You play as Adam Jensen, an experienced covert operative operating in a world that despises his kind: augmented humans. Choose from an arsenal of state-of-the-art weapons and augmentations to build your playstyle, and decide who you'll trust, to unravel a vast worldwide conspiracy.

Ban one of these hacking kids and they'll just re-download the game on a new account and hack again. great game! only one game mode right now and not many players but it's early access. Tell your friends to try it there needs to be more players!!!

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
name: Spiral Knights
reviews:
this game is better than everything else ................ Spiral knights.... Where to begin? 
Probably one of the best Free MMO's to come out of the early days, the game has it's flaws.
But between the pay-to-win garbage you can see glimpses of true brilliance. It's far from a bad game, and it has aged very well but... It's honestly a tragedy. The feeling of the old-school zelda games combined with fast-paced bullet hell, and some very creative and rewarding gameplay variance, all of this is there just mired under time and added on pay-to-win. Trinkets are a good idea, extra weapons slots? not really as the dichotimy of the three weapons types mean two is enough for everyone who aint a munchkin but the price for what you need is not too high, it is not unreachable in normal play- far from it. It just isn't instant. It takes a lot less time to farm then in many MMO's for most things you will need too.
This is probably one of my favorite games, but is also the single most I have ever been dissapointed by a game. Trinkets could have totally changed play-style by adding unique abilities like out Spirits do, but as it is they are a sub-par extra chunk of armor that costs real money to rent slots to wear it. Things like that, glimpses of true brilliance through the murk. I know it's there somewhere.
short_description: Join the ranks of the Spiral Knights. Stranded on an alien world, you must explore the ever-changing Clockworks beneath its surface.

name: Shadow Warrior
reviews:
samurai doom The game feels quite grindy by 2025 standards, though it probably didnâ€™t feel that way in 2013 when it was released. [h1]The Shadow Warrior Reboot is a perfect argument for a â€žThumbs to the sideâ€œ-rating on Steam.[/h1]

Shadow Warrior 2013 is a perfectly average first-person-shooter. It does many things right, only a few things wrong and is in my opinion more enjoyable than the original these days. But in my case, it was pretty much the same things that already bothered me in the original, that hold the reboot back as well, just in a different way.

Just like in the original, my main pain points in the reboot are again the level- and enemy design and the gunplay. Where the original had frustratingly cryptic levels, the reboot has levels that are too linear, too drab, too visually uninteresting and generally too boring. Where the original had enemies that are simply annoying to fight, the reboot keeps itâ€™s enemy variety to a minimum. The only thing that hasnâ€˜t changed for better or worse at all is the feel of the gunplay. The arsenal still felt weird (for lack of a better term) and unsatisfying (except for the shotgun), making the combat pretty dull and repetitive in combination with the nonexistent enemy variety. 

All of this makes the game drag significantly with itâ€™s 10 to 12 hours of playtime. Add on top an unnecessary and confusing story and you have basically a game that you buy, play once or maybe twice, then forget about. As mentioned Shadow Warrior 2013 is a solid game for what it is, but definitely not much more than a fairly tasty apetizer for the much better Shadow Warrior 2 and 3.
______________________________

SHADOW WARRIOR (2013)
Genre: First-Person-Shooter
Release: Q3 2013

name: Dead Space (2008)
reviews:
I went into Dead Space (mostly) blind and I was hooked from the start. Fantastic gameplay, fascinating story, mysteries upon mysteries, and so many unexpected twists. I must have built up some immunity to the scares by the end as my aim got so much better, but even up to the final levels, the game still knows how to maintain tension and keep you on your toes.

Add this to your library and make us whole. They don't make them like they used to Itâ€™s a claustrophobic, brutal journey into deep space that feels as heavy and cold as the ship it takes place on.
[h2]The Story:[/h2]You play as Isaac Clarke, an engineer,just a guy with a plasma cutter looking for his girlfriend, Nicole, on the USG Ishimura.The ship has gone silent, and the crew has been replaced by "Necromorphs".
[spoiler] The psychological gut-punch at the end is what makes this story legendary. Finding out that Nicole had been dead the entire time, and the "Marker" (the alien artifact) was using Isaacâ€™s dementia to manipulate him into helping it, turns a simple rescue mission into a tragic descent into madness.  [/spoiler]
[h2]Gameplay:[/h2] The genius of Dead Space is that it forces you to unlearn everything. In most games, you aim for the head. Here, a headshot is a waste of ammo. You have to cut off the limbs. Using mining tools to surgically dismember monsters while they sprint at you is stressful and incredibly satisfying.
[h2]Graphics & Sound:[/h2] Even by today's standards, the Ishimura looks fantastic in its own rusted, disgusting way. The lighting is oppressive, using flickering bulbs and deep shadows to hide things youâ€™d rather not see. But the sound design is the real MVP. The way the ship "groans," the screams echoing through the vents, and the silence of the vacuum sections are masterfully executed.
[h2]The Bad Parts:[/h2] Padding and Turrets It's not all smooth sailing. The game suffers from excessive backtracking; youâ€™ll find yourself running through the same corridors multiple times just to flip a switch. Also, the ADS (Anti-Asteroid) turret sequence is widely hated it's a clunky, frustrating mini-game that feels completely out of place in a survival horror masterpiece. Additionally, some of the "boss" encounters are more about scripted patterns than the creative combat the rest of the game encourages.
[h2]Outro[/h2] Dead Space isn't just a classic; itâ€™s a masterclass in pacing and tension. It treats the player with respect by not over explaining the horror, letting the cold metal of the Ishimura tell the story. If you can handle the gore and the constant feeling of being hunted, itâ€™s a journey you have to take at least once.
8,5/10
short_description: You are Isaac Clarke, an engineer on the spacecraft USG Ishimura. You're not a warrior. You're not a soldier. You are, however, the last line of defense for the remaining living crew.

name: Orcs Must Die! 3
reviews:
Nice A cool game to play alone, but it's way better when played with friends, especially when everyone has no idea what is even going on. This game was my introduction to the series, and I'm a big fan of it! Its a good mix between tower defense and first person shooter. The early rounds are more manually handled, while the later rounds are pretty much exclusively dealt with by traps. Lots of fun and interesting combinations, with many upgrades and ideas to try out. 

Grab the game on sale! It plays well solo, and REALLY well in Coop! I also really like the Tipping the Scales DLC. I had to adjust some trap combinations to deal with the new enemy type, and enjoyed the challenge. I personally didn't care for the Cold as Eyes DLC, since the Shaman enemies that put totems to disable your trap annoyed me. Its a personal preference, but I don't care for mechanics that disable things you've placed and planned out in tower defense games.
short_description: Slice, burn, toss, zap, grind and gib massive hordes of repugnant orcs in this long-awaited successor to the award-winning Orcs Must Die! series.

name: Toribash
reviews:
bit of [strike]Quality[/strike] bant this is a great game 10/10 I really  recomend downloading this game if you are into fighting games I've played this game quite a lot in the past before it was released to Steam. By no means was I good, especially since the game has a rather large learning curve. This learning curve comes from the fact that various joints must be manipulated to get results, but casual players (especially friends) will often find hilarity due to the manipulation of their characters sometimes in rather awkward positions. Multiplayer games are rather fast-paced compared to singleplayer sessions due to the timer which limits the time players can think before it runs out. Otherwise, various mods come with the game which adds plenty of PvP options (arena type, weapons, body sensitivity, etc.), or solo challenges (parkour, skateboarding, sports, etc.).

In terms of play by more seasoned/veteran players (not including myself), other players can find interest in the rather complicated techniques used to simulate real fights or complete parkour maps.

Overall, this game takes a long time to fully understand since the tutorial does not completely cover everything, but once players get past this, they'll find many challenges to overcome.
short_description: Toribash is an innovative free-to-play online turn-based fighting game where youâ€™re able to design your own moves. Complete control over character's body, hundreds of game mods and bloody mess with full body dismemberment - you've never been able to annihilate your enemies like that before!

name: Thunder Tier One
reviews:
Crazy potential. Too bad it didn't become more popular. Well worth it to fuck around in with friends, since it's completely free.  This review should be a "meh" but of course steam doesn't let you do that.
I bought this game years ago and didn't think about until a friend suggested we play it and trying it again I cannot recommend it.

The singleplayer is very short. 6h tops.
The selection of weapons, rigs, plate carriers/rigs is ridiculously small.
There is nothing exceptional about this game.
There isn't a lot of worthwhile mods or anything that will give this game a longer life.

Seems like they wanted something like Doorkickers and just came up with this and then forgot about it.

Save whatever time you were going to spend on it and play something with more of a value to it. This used to be a payed for title. i just found out it went free. At that price i can safely say Yes pick it up.
short_description: Thunder Tier One is a realistic top-down shooter where you join an elite special operations team tasked with stopping a dangerous terrorist organization wreaking havoc across the fictional Eastern European country of Salobia.

name: CyberCorp
reviews:
This is a pretty middle-ground review that leans towards "recommended". 

If you are like me and love the rare twin-stick-shooter aRPG then CyberCorp is worth looking into. This is quite similar to Housemarque's "Alienation" game. It leans more into looting and "buildcraft" than Alienation did, but doesn't feel quite as good to play.

I'm going to focus primarily on feedback and gameplay-feel. Game-feel is a bit all over the place. On the one hand, shooting with the various gun types does generally feel good. Unfortunately [b]hitting things does not.[/b] Enemies do not register hits particularly well, especially powerful ones. They don't flinch, knockback is almost nonexistent, and explosions don't knock them down. They ragdoll on death and that's it. 

This bad feedback issue is at it's worst when it comes to the games novel "style meter" mechanic. It's similar to Devil May Cry's mechanic of the same name, but tied to things like active reloads, slide dodges, multi-kills, and most importantly, finishers. The higher your style (from D-S) the more leeway you get with active reloads and the less damage you need to inflict on enemies before you can perform a finisher.

This mechanic works really well at increasing the pace of combat! -but the issue is that the finishers have all the impact of watching a 4 year old smash action figures against each other. The zoomed out presentation, the lengthy and sometimes very sloppy animations just make every finisher feel like an awkward mid-combat pause and not a triumphant mini-victory.

Frankly, I think finisher animations should just be removed (but the instant kill mechanic remain), or replaced with faster, flashier ones that need more particles or visual effects to sell their importance. I would even argue for something like a Shinobi style finisher where ALL enemies at the HP threshold are killed in one finisher. This would prevent the annoying (but safe) tactic of tapping "A" over and over on a group of weak enemies so you get to stay invincible during the lengthy animation.

The game also suffers from being a looter-shooter with extremely boring end-game content. The exotic weapons are typically more hindered than helped by their gimmicks, and there's little incentive to do anything but grind the same handful of missions over and over. Some of these missions randomize enemy spawns, but most do not, and the end result is an aRPG in desperate need of some kind of endless or lengthy randomly generated dungeon. very bland, repetetive, with boring story, and so buggy we couldnt play coop i have tried my hardest to like this game but playing this game solo even in the early goings is pretty shit. There really isnt an effective means to handle multiple enemies at once. Your guns and sword are far too weak even at the recommended gear level and you special abilites nearly all have far too long of a cooldown timer, which is typical for the genre, but trash all the same. I have made it up to the 9th mission but it's just far too tedious for me to bother to continue. I definitely dont recommend this to anyone
short_description: Brutal fast-paced isometric Co-op Loot Shooter in Cyberpunk world. Equipment-based combos. Exotic Weapons and Armor. Easy to start, hard to master. Play solo or with friends.

reviews:
I have nostalgia for this game When I was little, I used to watch my father playing this game during the golden age of the PlayStation 2. I got a PC and saw this gem was available on Steam, undoubtedly one of the greatest hits. Other than the vehicle controls being 180'd
love it.

noticed the jedi star fighter removed on the naboo plains which is okay but was my go to.
Glad they  made the switch between 1st and 3rd player the right joystick unlike they original console version.

Still my favorite game for the PS2/XBOX era
short_description: Fight the greatest battles in the STAR WARS universe any way you want to. The choice is yours.

name: Stormgate
reviews:
robodog. I saw the "mixed" and had to voice my discontent. This was a huge bait and switch. Looked like the game needed funding in EA. Was fun, looked promising. Purchased the Ultimate Edition. On launch much just like every other backer I was disgusted. 

I'm not buying it twice... and its a spit in the face of everyone that had your back. 

Also the fact you use AI at all is another concern all together Played the game when it came out (first go around) and you could clearly tell it was made from blizz employees, remembering some of the maps i could practically feel thhe 'thrall' energy from warcraft 3 on the tutorial level, you could see some of the old re-hashed content, and you know what? that must be pretty tough adjusting mindset away from it to be fairly unique, standng on their own two feet. the gameplay wasnt to bad. ai wasnt to bad to verse, but personally i was interested more in the story. so the first round thhe game came out i would say "reusing same materials". however this second go around? the revamped campaign? levels have been redone, theres a few resuses in there, but it isnt 'shotty'. theres alot it has to offer in there. units look like they got some enhancements, cinimatic moments feel better, its a good start. heres the "do i know if the game is quality?" check or am i just some slump, who picked this up as my first rts. like i would hope alot of you have checked your p's and q's. i've played command and conquer (full series and let me tell you this aint no c&c 4) starcraft + broodwar, warcraft 1, 2, 3, tft. armies of exigo, empire earth, aoe, aom. 

this game aint bad, and i think its pretty good the devs seem open to feedback. i think the factions are done pretty well, maybe a little tweaking to the Celestial units wouldnt be a bad move (more so because they 'feel' small you know? like a 'tank' like unit feels like i got a tricycle with a horn on the front, but thats just redesign right? structure wise they feel kinda pyramid-ish? like they dont got 'make me feel like im a cybernetic angel lord' vibes, but thats just tweaking cosmetics, infernals i think handle well, a little spammy, but they seam like heavy hitters (best way for me to describe it, is imagine playing diablo, but your playing for team diablo. XD) Vanguard aint bad either i mean its your terran faction yea, but they got some unique tastes on them, melee is one of the odd parts, but welcome. the bunkers could use a redesign imo but other then that, again not so bad.

as for the 'skrimish' gameplay, one mode thats a 'wtf' is the stormgates coming up, and then rushing along to beat back the opposition so you can destroy the stormgate and get the bonus unit (its a cool gameplay feature but i think it might be better used as one of those boxes around the map you can randomly pick up. or like a warcraft 3 'item' you got from mobs, aint nothing wrong with that bit of nostalgia.) id recommend more maps, maybe play around with how units handle and stuff, but thats just my opinion. i mean lets be honest here as well, this is the closest thing to a 'starcraft 3' or warcraft 4 as you can get right now. i think it would be better to help them out, and support it, give some decent feedback. you dont think other marketing teams arent gunna look at this kinda stuff and go "sheesh are we sure we wanna make another....?" just some food for thought. never know whats going on under wraps, they could use your support if their struggling. 
  
(and to be honest id rather have that 'slap to the face' of free-to-play then watching month long grinds on WoW get sold up as cosmetics.)
short_description: Stormgate is a free-to-play RTS in active development. Featuring competitive 1v1, 3P co-op missions, and an evolving campaign, Frost Giant aims to build the next great RTS, guided by player feedback. A 3v3 mode is also on the way, so join our development journey today!

name: Medieval Dynasty
reviews: A very detailed game with good progression. Great Game This is the most needlessly complicated game I have ever seen in my life. There is ten times too much info on your screen at any given time, and the UI is really hard to understand, since everything opens up another menu and it's missing a lot of QOL features. My first NPC got stuck on a rock somewhere, and I couldn't assign him a hut no matter where I clicked or what menu I looked through. Beyond that, the houses take way too long to build and you have to do it all by yourself. Everything feels slow and the fact that the wine item has 6 different stat effects should tell you everything you need to know about how overly complicated this game is. I cannot stress enough how wide-as-an-ocean deep-as-a-puddle this game is. Good luck crafting anything with the combo of twelve different radial menus, equipping items, and your crafting materials each having their own real-time stats.
short_description: Hunt, survive, build and lead in the harsh Middle Ages: Create your own Medieval Dynasty and ensure its long-lasting prosperity or die trying! Play alone or team up with friends to enjoy the ultimate medieval experience.

name: Crysis 2 - Maximum Edition
reviews:
Visually and gameplay-wise this game still holds up very well today. Effects, textures and models all look sharp and the gameplay feels fluid and tactile. 

My advice is to get this instead of buying the more expensive remaster. you wont have any complaints running this on the highest settings and the only thing that the remaster provides is a multiplayer experience that isnt totally dead (yet) The story expands extremely well on the first game, really showing the aftermath of the Crysis 1's conclusion very well. The characters are extremely engaging, but the supporting cast didn't feel quite as engaging as your squadmates in the first one.

Also, I feel that the combat was not nearly as enjoyable in this one. Enemies feel like a bullet sink more often than actually being difficult, and headshots are beyond inconsistent. The suit feels downgraded from the original; I played full stealth in the first entry, and that felt almost impossible here.

TL;DR - this was a great follow-up storywise, but I felt the gameplay was a little bit lacking. Link to review: https://backloggd.com/u/RedBackLoggd/review/3481362/

Tl;dr -- If you like first-person shooters, you canâ€™t go wrong with Crysis 2. It has its issues for sure, but as an entertaining venture with a deeply-revised story, it succeeds in holding its ownâ€¦.for the most part.
short_description: Aliens are decimating New York City, only you have the technology to survive. Be The Weapon.

Solid 10/10 game and I've only played 24 hours of it no idea how the navy works but good game ig worst game ive ever played i cant stop 10/10

name: Half-Life: Alyx
reviews:
It was worth enduring all the trouble of getting my setup to work, occasionally not having a room to do roomscale in, bumping into crap in my tiny room when playing seated, exhaustion, motion sickness, and my heavy headset leaving marks on my face.. I had attempted so many times to play this game but could never do it due to all of that. This time, for some reason, something clicked and I actually couldn't put it down. I just *had* to finish it.

I love how manual so many of the actions in the game are. That adds tension to the gameplay which otherwise wouldn't exist outside VR. Searching for objects is also pretty fun. I definitely didn't find all the resin the first go, but that's fine.

My one and only critique: throwing objects is a pain. Remember Wii Sports Bowling? How you have to pretend throw your controller and the ball ends up going backwards? I feel like I experienced that sorta thing here and there. Maybe I suck at throwing things in VR who knows lol

I could definitely see myself coming back to play this again once better headsets and living conditions are available to me. another decade of no hl3 If you're thinking of buying this game, just buy it already. Even 5 years later it is unmatched (imo) with the detail of immersion it offers with its rich story telling and gameplay. For example, liquid in a beer bottle slosh or that all items in cabinets can be picked up and broken. Just the type of detail valve does. During the more horror aspect level there are some times I had to rip off my head, and had my heart racing (granted a whip when it comes to horror).
short_description: Half-Life: Alyx is Valveâ€™s VR return to the Half-Life series. Itâ€™s the story of an impossible fight against a vicious alien race known as the Combine, set between the events of Half-Life and Half-Life 2. Playing as Alyx Vance, you are humanityâ€™s only chance for survival.

You could say, you want to progress, just for the progression, and to see the story end - but the the mechanics don't really develop with it. I do like the humor which can be found in the little chats you will have throughout the game.

name: Fallout 76
reviews:
If you want a game that has had every opportunity to fix itself and listen to it's audience but would rather try and nickel and dime the player base this is the one. If you don't pay for fallout first the inventory management becomes the main part of the game. Combat enemies never get easier and it'll actually be harder to kill the level 100 raider wearing leather armor than it is to kill the level 100 3 star legendary mythical flying **cking bat. 
So glad that years in the making this game still is just as bad as the day it launched. If someone at bethesda could let me know why my brute of a character can take on bosses and body them but randomly they decide to roid out their most bare minimum bottom barrel opponent that takes more than half my ammo inventory to take out, 20+ **ckas* respawns that should not be necessary in the first place. 
Honest to god you'd be better off playing a rage simulator while watching your wife from the cuck chair for a more enjoyable experience. 
Can't forget that there's entire broken missions and story lines that can't be completed but the instructions clutter your screen and compass despite there being no resolution.  Sure you can go into the pipboy and turn off the notification but that doesn't excuse the fact that this game is 10 years old and they still can't manage to make a mission that is both cohesive and finished. 
That being said, if you are searching for a game that offers little to no satisfaction this is it. If you want a game where you fall through the floor on spawn and you can't use the weapon wheel without the game coming to 3 fps, again this is it. 
The only thing this game has going for it is its "sims" like camp building features and they can't even get that done correctly as you run out "build allowance" as soon as you add more than minimal detail. Then again minimal detail seems to be what the developers are going for, that and how terribly can we optimize this game before it becomes unplayable. Alright game This game is a trap.

It preys on people who have Fear of missing out, and people who want to show off their camps/items.

You enjoy the game at first, feel immersed exploring and doing fun story missions and so on. Then you get to a point where, to get better stuff you need to grind faction reputation, Gold bullions, public events and so on, and without realising you enter this loop of grinding to get those items to "have a better decorated camp". 

Fallout first is a trap of its own too: You should never have to pay for a subscription to store your loot in a "game", you would think you are getting a good deal because you get 1600 atoms every month but you realise its nothing because of the overpriced re skinned items they put in the shop. 

I gave this game a 3 year break, then came back to see if it is in a better state, nope, still very buggy, bad graphics, and worse than before in the FOMO element, it seems like they are trying their bare minimum to keep you playing and subscribed to fallout 1st.

Word of advice: If you really want to play this game, get it for 12 USD or less, play the main story and side  quests, then stop before you fall into their looped trap, there is a reason you see players level 500-1000+ on average.
short_description: Bethesda Game Studios welcome you to Fallout 76. Twenty-five years after the bombs fall, you and your fellow Vault Dwellers emerge into post-nuclear America. Explore a vast wasteland in this open-world multiplayer addition to the Fallout story.

I really hope they address this issue in their next iteration of the game (for reference of games with decent melee combat you could look at Chivalry or Dark and Darker... hell I would even like a combat similar to Skyrim, I'm not asking that much!) Maybe some nice concepts but it's far to janky and not for me sure

Explore the vast world of Aurai solo or in Co-op. The Definitive Edition features both DLCs and quality of life improvements.

However it can get annoying as when for example, when attacking a province or the capital, the AI will literally commit a "setarmy 5000" or whatever and just summon way more troops than you have on the border out of nowhere.
Also the mechanic that you can make your own Countries and formables gives the game just more creativity and in the degree that it is a sandbox.
Overall, pretty fun and simple game, would reccomend.

reviews:
this game is soooooo DIFICULT but i love it and its a really good game :D Peak story telling and ai mainly the lizards and scavs
20/10 would i recommend this game? of course i would. i'd recommend and force my friends to play this game so that i can watch the suffering appear on their faces. so that i can document how agony is engraved into their very soul with each death. yes. yes i would recommend. rain world is like when you get thrown into a box full of rabid wild animals and you're expected to fight them all and break out of that box like my boy Sisyphus Prime Ultrakill, survive mobile cancerous cysts that want to devour your DNA, eat some lady's few remaining neurons for a quest, dropkick a god and then find the fissure in the world itself that gets you into the afterlife or whatever. Rain world is the game that made me realize just how bad it would be if miros birds were real, and how much i want to live in the shaded citadel and eat fried coalescipedes. thank you rain world. thank you for raining my world.

name: Ravenfield
reviews:
I've owned and played Ravenfield fairly frequently since 2017. I enjoy the game and will pick it up for sessions from time to time even still, but I can't in good faith recommend this to people in it's current state especially having played it for so long. 

First, it's coming into it's almost ninth year of early access. I understand that it's being lead by a solo developer, but nine years of early access is a bit much. Granted I've seen the changes and they've been good but when you put it into perspective it doesn't really change much. Better models, slightly better (still shit) AI, some new maps and a clunky new gamemode. That basically sums up the big stuff. Ravenfield has the same short comings as Easy Red 2, where the AI sucks no matter what they do to it. Ravenfield needs a total AI overhaul. For example, literally since the game has come out, if you spawn on Dustbowl and attempt to get into a plane on the airfield, the AI will suicide run into your plane and instantly fall over/die. In a ground vehicle? They love to run in front of you. It's little stuff like that which is plain stupid.

But the big reason I find it hard to recommend this game is the horrific performance issues it's had since it released. I have played this game on varying pieces of hardware, from downright bad laptops to powerful computers. It has only performed well on higher end machines which would be fine if the game didn't look like playdough. 

But if you really want to buy and play the game despite it's flaws, do it. I still enjoy it and have played it on and off for nearing a decade now. It's a labor of love but that doesn't mean it's not deserving of criticism. Once it's fully released (which I think is coming in 2026), I will revisit this review. it is a good game i like th eshoting good game, modding scene could use some work but major potential.
short_description: Fight upon the Ravenfield together with your Blue allies! Take down those pesky Reds using helicopters, tanks, guns, and active ragdoll physics!

name: Enclave
reviews:
Adding russian voiceover to a 22-year-old game in the fourth year of the largest war in Europe since World War II, unleashed by russian terrorists, is an incredible disgrace. It's really odd that after all these years of this game sitting abandoned by Starbreeze, only to receive an update out of the blue. Was the game patched to work properly on modern systems? Nope! Still a broken mess. So what changed? Good question!

They added RU translations to the game, that's it. You know, the nation that invaded another nation unprovoked, the nation committing crimes against humanity? Yeah, that one! Of course the publisher claims they have good relations on both sides, but no UA translation in sight. Bought a used Xbox copy well over a decade ago thinking it was going to be open world like Morrowind, ten year old me was sorely mistaken. Game itself is serviceable, has some of the coolest menu FMVs.
short_description: Experience incredibly atmospheric and intense medieval combat action! Go ahead and enter a new world, the award-winning world of ENCLAVE!The people of Light and Darkness are divided by a bottomless rift that split the earth many millennia ago.

reviews: Been playing on and off since Beta, and this is a really good game. It is easy to play, but a grind to master. I love how I constantly feel like I am progressing. I love how the games looks. I love how chill it feels to play, and that it can be played on mobile. It is just a fun MMO, but it does have some force PvP in order to get some of the higher materials, which is a wall for me since I hate PvP. Despite that, I still have fun playing this, and chilling out doing what ever I want. Bots owning the marketplace ruining any non-guild or small guilds chance to sell something at a decent price. People hacking into accounts and stealing all the materials you have access to and the admins/company doing literally nothing about it, even if you don't even want your stuff back, you just want the hackers banned. Also barely any active english speaking guilds relative to just about every other language, at least on american servers( this may have changed by now, but I doubt it). Guilds wanting people to simply farm mats and fame for them, with little to no reward. Meanwhile solo play you get ganked or have to run from every group of players you run across. Not having premium is basically torture when trying to level up any skills or even get your moneys back on farms for your island. These are the reasons why I've quit playing even though I only put 200 hours into the game. Id say the only perk is that it's a free to play game. So give it a shot if you plan to play only 1 game for the rest of your life. HOPE I FIZ IT TO STEAM FAST EASIER HÃ…PER JEG FIKSER DE TIL STEAM SNART RASKERE Ã… LETERE

name: Dragon Ageâ„¢: The Veilguard
reviews:
Most of the negative reviews I've seen are about this game not being like previous installments, or something along those lines, but I've never played a Dragon Age game before this one and therefore I went into this game with zero expectations. I enjoyed it quite a lot, and will likely be playing again in the future to try out different choices and decisions. 

The character creator is really great, and I especially love the hair styles and physics. Combat was good and I liked the various powers and buffs you could play with. I enjoyed the story, although there were a few things that bugged me here and there about it, and the "blight" concept feels kind of unoriginal and overdone. The companion characters were interesting, and I'm a sucker for a party system in combat. I enjoyed the voice acting and was properly invested in their survival. 

Performance was fine for me. There were a few minor bugs that restarting fixed. Some occasional lag in combat that was annoying, since I rarely experience that with games on this laptop. But overall ran well. 

Looting/treasure hunting was unsatisfying. Some of the chests require elaborate puzzles to get to, with very little pay off. You're just finding copies of weapons and armor, which can't be sold, and at a certain point in your progression, everything you're finding is useless to you because it's below your current stats. 

Overall this was probably a 7/10 for me. Definitely a fair amount of time and enjoyment since I picked it up for sale at 20-something bucks. Also, Manfred is amazing. Game crashes in the same spot, early on. I have a 7600X3D and 7800XT GPU... 32 GB ram... my system runs Stalker 2, Harry Potter, Outer Worlds 2, Baldur's Gate 3, etc., and every other game I've tried. All run flawlessly.  Flawlessly.  This game is bad news.  It's my final encounter with Ubisoft... a company that doesn't GAF about customers.  What a huge disappointment this was. I like the game. They retconned a LOT of lore, & I don't like it as much as I would've liked. They left a lot of potential lying on the table, especially with the standard that Inquisition set. I've always been a lore nerd, though. The gameplay mechanics & graphics are much better than anything released in the franchise so far, though. Overall, it's a solid game. Not quite as good as I wanted it to be, but it's nice to play.
short_description: Unite the Veilguard and defy the gods in Dragon Ageâ„¢: The Veilguard, an immersive single-player RPG.

name: Golf With Your Friends
reviews:
I find this game really relaxing I am a 46 year old single father, and I am definitely not the target audience for a chaotic multiplayer mini golf game. My son, who is 15 now, asked me to buy Golf With Your Friends. He said it was fun, stupid in a good way, and something we could play together. I assumed it would be another game I sat next to him for, smiling and pretending to care.

At first, that is exactly what happened. I watched him and his friends bounce balls off walls, fall through holes, yell at each other, and laugh at the dumbest mistakes. Balls would fly off the map. Someone would rage quit. Everyone else would laugh. I did not get it. It looked loud, messy, and pointless. I wondered how this could possibly be fun.

One evening, after he went to bed, I loaded it up myself. No story. No tutorials that really mattered. Just a ball, a course, and gravity doing whatever it wanted. I missed easy shots. Overshot everything. Fell off the map more times than I can count. And then something clicked. I stopped trying to be good. I started laughing at how bad I was. I relaxed.

The next day, I told my son I played. He did not tease me. He did not brag. He just smiled and said, â€œPlay with me.â€ So we did. We argued over angles. We laughed at impossible bounces. Sometimes one of us would win, sometimes neither of us cared. The scores stopped mattering. The moments did not.

For the first time in a long while, we were not rushing. We were not distracted. We were just sitting together, laughing at stupid physics and bad shots, sharing something simple and light.

Thank you, Golf With Your Friends, for turning nonsense into connection, and for giving me a silly little space where I could meet my son halfway and just have fun with him. good
short_description: Why have friends if not to play Golf... With Your Friends! Nothing is out of bounds as you take on courses filled with fast paced, exciting, simultaneous mini golf for up to 12 players!

genres: Adventure, Casual, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy, Free To Play
name: Clicker Heroes
reviews: In Clicker Heroes, you play as John Mouse, and aim to collect all 151 Heroes! Yes It is fun because I click monsters and the hero levels are infinite. short_description: Click your way through hordes of monsters, earn gold, and recruit quirky heroes with powerful skills. Progress even while you're idle, and watch the numbers climb into the absurd. Itâ€™s a never-ending journey of clicks, crits, and colossal damage.

name: Age of Wonders III
reviews:
I love this game with all my heart. The base game is sublime, but the modding scene really makes it something special. I listen to the soundtrack when I'm in my car.

I just wish it was a little less prone to crashing, but it's still far more fun than the miserable 4th game. Pretty fun game, it's definitely worth the buy. I'll probably end up buying the others in the near future. Age of Wonders III â€“ Classic fantasy 4X with proper punchy battles

Age of Wonders III is basically the sweet spot between a fantasy Civilization and a tactical RPG â€“ and it leans just enough into both to feel great.

On the strategic layer, youâ€™re running a fantasy empire:

Founding and upgrading cities

Grabbing resources and magical sites

Expanding your domain with forts and outposts

Researching spells and empire upgrades

Nothing wildly experimental, but itâ€™s all smooth and satisfying, with a great sense of building up power over time.

The real magic is in the tactical battles. When armies clash, the game drops you into a hex-based battlefield where positioning, flanking, abilities and terrain actually matter.

Units have clear roles: tanks, glass-cannon damage dealers, support, flyers, artillery.

Heroes feel like mini-RPG characters: they level up, get gear, learn abilities and can turn a fight on their own if used well.

Spells from the world map can be dropped into battles for big, dramatic swings.

It hits that perfect fantasy-strategy loop: scout â†’ plan â†’ set up a nasty ambush â†’ win a fight that looked impossible because you used your tools well.

The races and classes are a big plus too. You donâ€™t just pick â€œelvesâ€ or â€œdwarvesâ€ â€“ you combine a race with a class (Sorcerer, Warlord, Dreadnought, etc.), which changes your units, spells and playstyle. A Dwarf Theocrat and an Elf Rogue feel properly different, even on the same map.

Downsides?

The AI can sometimes blob and carpet the map with armies rather than play â€œcleverlyâ€.

Late game turns can get a bit long when everyone has huge stacks wandering around.

The UI is very 2010s-PC â€“ functional, but not exactly elegant.

But overall, Age of Wonders III is a genuinely strong fantasy 4X with great tactical combat. If you like building an empire, nurturing a killer hero stack and then absolutely deleting enemy armies with well-timed spells and flanking maneuvers, it still holds up really well.
short_description: Age of Wonders III is the long anticipated sequel to the award-winning strategy series. Delivering a unique mix of Empire Building, Role Playing and Warfare, Age of Wonders III offers the ultimate in turn-based fantasy strategy for veterans of the series and new players alike!

short_description: A Way Out is an exclusively co-op adventure where you play the role of one of two prisoners making their daring escape from prison.

name: Monster Hunter Stories 2: Wings of Ruin
reviews:
Melhor que pokemon very good game I am finally ready to do my review of the game after 200 hours and getting the platinum trophy, and boy is it going to be a long one. I'm going to do this review a little bit differently than the rest because of the grade I'm giving it so let's get started. This game is going to start off with the good stuff, then the annoying stuff, then PSA's for new players because there's a lot the game doesn't tell you, and then finally some notes for the next game for the developers to make the game better in my opinion (I know the next game has already had a release date, but I hope these things are in MHS3 coming out in March).

Firstly, my rating for this game is a 4.7 out of 5 and was so so close to giving this game 5* it is by far the closest game in recent memory that I was going to rate as highly. I want to give a massive shout out to the audio and visual fx team, and the animators for this game. What a gorgeous game, from the battle animations, to the howl of the wind through the caves. When I had my headphones on this game made me feel like I was in the area that I was meant to be in, and narratively, they did an incredible job with the look of the game. There are also many many improvements over the first game such as the day/night cycles having different items, there's no more delay when exiting a fight to fight the next enemy, or the egg battles. I love the buddy system, having another person in the party makes it feel like a party, and the removal of the battle pouch was pretty nice. I love that as you go further into the game the environments get smaller, if you're like me and you like to explore everything before moving on, it's nice to do it all up front and then have the environments get smaller as you go along. And finally the addition of the new monsties, making all the eggs a different monstie, the boss battles, all of it was amazing. Overall such an incredible game, and so close to getting 5* from me. 

I want to briefly discuss the reason I can't go completely 5* on this and it has the same problem as the first game which is that the story makes no sense, and being that I'm a big narrative guy, it still feels like the story has more questions than answers, why did Red come to these places? Why are we doing random fetch quests like getting a little girl's necklace to go to the next area, why is Ena even travelling with us if she's not part of the party? As cool as it is to see the people from the first game, why are they randomly showing up in these places and have no reason to be there, etc. It's just the lack of cohesive storytelling that makes me can't give this a full 5* and the other thing is that the main character doesn't speak, but the good reasons I listed above do far outshadow this small issue.

Now some PSA's for new players on things to know the game doesn't tell you. 
First, I recommend playing MHS1. The game is significantly harder than this one, but only took me half the time and taught me all about the items so I wasn't a novice when I played this game. 
Higher rarity eggs are typically better than the eggs being rainbow or shiny. 
Adding Genes to a monster should benefit the attacks that the monster has, so if it has a poison attack, find a monstie to transfer that has the right gene for the build you're trying to go for. In addition, there is a secret system called gene upgrading in the rite of channeling. If you have two identical genes on two different monsties, you can overlap the same gene on the new monstie and make it even more powerful and gain stars to make a gene even stronger, so don't release monsties until you know if there's a gene you can transfer. 
You can use the "X" key while you're in the quest log to mark the location of monsties on your map if there's a side quest you can't find the location of.
 If you deal enough damage to a monster and it starts drooping down and drooling it gets the "Tired" status. It is a good time to use a paintball because there is a higher liklihood the monster is going to retreat (If it's retreatable) .
 Riding your monstie when you're afflicted with a status effect like blastblight, poison or electrified gets rid of the status condition completely without using an item, and switching monsties in battle can make your buddy use a different attack if he's going to lose the Head to Head. Kinship skills can also break monsters out of their final attack, or even ground dive. 
You can accept a quest at the job board multiple times by clicking enter when you go to the job board if there are quest rewards that you need multiples of.
 Reverto is not a rider, he's a hunter, so he deals non-elemental (raw) damage regardless of the enemies weakness. He is by far the strongest battle buddy, and you're best off supporting yourself and letting him go crazy with damage.
Hunting Horns are extremely strong, and are going to be necessary in the late game. Find one with the skill called Evasion Riff it blocks all damage for each member of your party for one attack and they are vital for upgrading in the late game
Also upgrading your weapon actually deals more damage to parts on the monster. It makes them easier to break. Upgrading weapons in the early game has almost no effect because you're going to be switching weapons in the early game so often that it's pointless to upgrade until you beat the story. 
Finally, Keep your old weapons. In the endgame if you upgrade them enough, they turn into higher rarity weapons so don't sell them for money because they upgrade easier than buying the rare ones already.

Finally I just want to give a couple notes to the developer that would make this game 5* from me. 
Firstly, I think you should make the house customizable. Allow basic furniture, or trophy displaying from certain kills in the game, I think it would be a way to get people more involved in designing their houses and make them play the game more. 
Next, I think that you should make the game one riding action per zone. The fact that I have to put every single riding action in my party in case I go to a zone where I need to ivy climb, and jump, and rock smash, etc means I can't customize my party the way I want to, I'm confined to have to use all the riding actions if I want all the items. 
Finally, have a multi-character progression system. Basically, have things you can transfer to another character. It would increase replayability in the game and allow for things like a new game + mode, instead of just making the monsters harder, this would be sort of an ultimate challenge with a sliding difficulty. There's not really much point to me starting another character beyond the first one, and this would give me a reason to play another character. 

Thanks for listening, and it is well worth the money, buy it!

name: Pathfinder: Wrath of the Righteous - Enhanced Edition
reviews:
very good I put 50+ hours into this game and was largely enjoying it. There was enough that I really liked (e.g., a diverse array of class options, challenging encounters that required adaptation, etc.) that it was worth playing around some of the standing bugs that I ran into (e.g., in combat, sometimes having my healer waste their action because they didn't automatically move as part of the spell casting). 

Then I hit a game ending bug, also apparently a standing issue - the game stopped recognizing all keyboard controls. The usual fix didn't do the trick. I tried putting all the essential controls on my mouse, but then the game stopped recognizing those as well. And that was the end of my playthrough... as well as the end of my patience with Owlcat. 

I gave Pathfinder WotR a chance after also hitting a game ending bug on Kingmaker (after 130+ hours of play). I'm done giving Owclat the benefit of the doubt. They've lost me as player for good.

[spoiler] There is also a point in game when one Woljif, one of the playable companions runs away. Woljif was part of my main party, so I lost access to all of the items Woljif had equipped and had to rebalance my entire party. The game broke for me shortly after this, so I looked up whether Woljif comes back. The answer is apparently yes, but after a prolonged absence (i.e., you would have to redistribute items and rebalance the party again, after having to invest effort into building a companion you don't intend to stick with). I have no idea why they thought this was a remotely good idea. It doesn't add anything, other than frustration. [/spoiler] What a game! 

I finished my first playthrough and immediately started the second. 
Story, companions, extra fun with Mythic paths - such a step up from Kingmaker. 

Daeran is probably my favourite romance option among all the RPGs I've played; he's so beautifully written. 
Regill is an absolute sweetheart. 

The only downside of the game for me was crusade mode, but it's easy to overcome once you figure out how everything works. 

Easily one of the best RPGs out there.
short_description: Embark on a journey to a realm overrun by demons in a new epic RPG from the creators of the critically acclaimed Pathfinder: Kingmaker. Explore the nature of good and evil, learn the true cost of power, and rise as a Mythic Hero capable of deeds beyond mortal expectations.

It's rather short, but it's worth it if you're invested in the Alan Wake universe. The gameplay is a bit more Rambo-like when compared to Alan Wake 1, but what game isn't? I'm glad I played it. Story didnt really hook me like the main game but it was a fun goofy little experience that I would recommend if your a fan of Alan Wake. Pick this one up when its on sale though.

name: Capcom Arcade Stadium
reviews:
That's Great Collection!
I bought some titles per it, But I bought all titles bundle at last.
I hope and hope, next "Capcom Consumer staduim" Please Capcom! Classic arcade games that are still fun to play today. I really wanted to like Capcom Arcade Stadium â€” the idea of having a collection of classic arcade titles all in one place sounds great on paper. Unfortunately, the execution leaves a lot to be desired.

The emulation feels off, with noticeable input lag and inconsistent performance across different games. Even on solid hardware, frame pacing and slowdown issues pop up far too often. The CRT scan line filters are also underwhelming â€” even at 1440p, they look artificial and donâ€™t capture the authentic arcade look.

It honestly comes across as another quick cash grab rather than a carefully crafted preservation effort. Iâ€™ve built PCs with better emulation setups in the past that run these same games smoother and with more accurate visuals.

Not worth my time here. Sorry, Capcom â€” this one just doesnâ€™t hold up.

Verdict: â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†â˜† (2/5) â€“ Decent concept, poor execution.
short_description: Relive the Capcom classics! Get 1943 -The Battle of Midway- and game logo wallpapers free with your download!

name: SpiritfarerÂ®: Farewell Edition
reviews:
I loved the storytelling and peacefulness of this game. Tackles big themes with cute art. [h1] Spiritfarer [/h1]

There are games about death, and then thereâ€™s Spiritfarer â€” a game about saying goodbye, not by fighting or killing, but by walking alongside others until theyâ€™re ready to let go.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] What I Loved [/h2]
[b]Spiritfarer is a hand-drawn masterpiece[/b] â€” yes, its animation is traditionally hand-drawn, frame by frame, and it shows in every movement and expression.

The game gently explores the lives of people who fell ill or suffered accidents, helping them complete what they couldnâ€™t finish in life so they can depart in peace. [b]Emotionally powerful[/b] is an understatement â€” it had been a long time since a game made me cry like this.

The experience is long, calm, and meant to be savored slowly, truly embracing that [i]cozy[/i] feeling, with a soundtrack that will give you chills.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] What Could Improve [/h2]
Some tasks can become [b]repetitive[/b], especially late-game activities like watering plants or harvesting crops. A bit of automation at that stage would have helped.
A few quests lack clear guidance, and since the map is surprisingly large, this can lead to a lot of aimless wandering before figuring out what youâ€™re missing.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Final Verdict [/h2]
[b]9/10 â€” Highly Recommended.[/b]
Spiritfarer is almost perfect: a beautiful, heartfelt journey about life, loss, and closure. Just a couple of small design friction points keep it from being flawless â€” but the emotional impact more than makes up for it. good game
short_description: SpiritfarerÂ® is a cozy management game about dying. As ferrymaster to the deceased, build a boat to explore the world, care for your spirit friends, and release them into the afterlife. The Spiritfarer Farewell Edition includes the heartwarming base game and three major content updates.

name: Teardown
reviews: would not reccomend it got me addicted gud very explosive buy I like this game, but it has a few flaws that hold it back for me. The mission types in the main story boil down to some simple tasks where you break into a place and either steal or destroy a variety of items. I would say that this game fits perfectly in the sandbox and puzzle game genres. The main problem that I have with it are the timed missions. These will have you doing some task, but on a short timer. I don't think that these are very creative or fun, as the timer is so extremely short that there is only really one right 'answer'. The game engine itself seems capable of tons of creative missions, but they don't actually explore these options and instead make similar missions over and over. "I need you to break into Y and fetch X. X is attached to an alarm, so when you touch it you have 60 seconds to get all of them across the whole map." BORING. The other lame mission type is centered around an attack helicopter that follow you the whole mission. It is completely indestructible, even though you have access to a rocket launcher and on one map a literal AA cannon. The helicopter also never loses sight of you, and of course can shoot at and destroy most cover. What I'm saying is that you might as well be fighting God, as the pilot can see you at all times and can't be destroyed or even hindered in any way. These missions aren't really "hard" in the traditional way, mostly because of quicksaves, but they also aren't fun. Other than these mission types, the game is fun and the sandbox is a blast, but those missions really do sour the main campaign enough to where I wouldn't recommend.
short_description: Prepare the perfect heist in this simulated and fully destructible voxel world. Tear down walls with vehicles or explosives to create shortcuts. Stack objects to reach higher. Use the environment to your advantage in the most creative way you can think of.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access

reviews:

name: Mortal Kombat Komplete Edition
reviews: Its an exemplary port of the XBOX 360 version of MK9 with all DLC. Worth evry penny. Mortal Kombat (9) Komplete Edition is the game that revived the franchise. Honestly, there's not much more to add: it's simply amazing. Just be aware that some tweaks may be needed to run it on modern operating systems, and that the multiplayer mode is now deserted (servers are basically down). They removed it from the steam store, so thumbs down. This game is for boss's. Warner Bro's Sucks Major Ass for removing it.

Players enter the realm to face the Kombatants in Mortal Kombat Komplete Edition, delivering all of the downloadable content (DLC), including intrepid warriors Skarlet, Kenshi and...

name: Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night
reviews:
lili form It's very good. The Castlevania reboot of your dreams.

Bloodstainde: Ritual of the Night is everything Mighty Number 9 wanted to be.  This is a true blue castlevania game, but with a whole new universe to explore and learn about.  This is made by a famous creator who was instrumental in creating the original series this is based on, and this game lives up to all the promises that were made during the kickstarter campaign.

Now, taking the history of this game out of the equation, this is still a fantastic Metroidvania with fun writing, cool levels and map design, awesome abilities, and great controls.  On top of the usual metroidvania abilities and platforming, this game also includes a secondary ability system and an armor/weapon system that's combined with a cosmetics system, so everything you equip can also be seen on your character.  The secondary ability system is similar to the ability system in Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow, where when you kill an enemy, there is a chance you will obtain an equipable ability from them.  This has its pros and cons, as it's great there is so much content, but if you want something particular or to complete everything, you're in for a lot of grinding.

On top of the great main campaign, there are also additional modes to play.  Boss rush, speed-run, and a second campaign where you play as a boss going through the whole game.  There is a LOT of content in this game.

While this IS a great game, it isn't perfect.  The game is obviously lower budget as it doesn't look quite as nice as it could, even for when it came out.  On top of that, the game screen can be a little difficult to read the screen because the foreground (what you can use) and the background (just visuals) are sometimes not as distinct as they could be.  These shouldn't really detract from how great this game is, but every game has it's flaws.

If you want another great metroidvania to play, this is a GREAT option, and the newly announced sequel (as of this writing) it's an even better time to jump on this game.
short_description: Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night is an exploration-focused, side-scroller action RPG by Koji Igarashi. Play as Miriam, an orphan scarred by an alchemist's curse that slowly crystallizes her body. Battle through a demon-infested castle and defeat its master to save yourself, and all of humanity!
