name: Unrailed!
reviews: Very underrated game. Might seem peaceful from the trailers but don't let it deceive you. 10/10 must play. Muy bueno, Es ideal para jugar en un televisor con controles y amigos. Good simple game to play with the wife. She loves it when I dash into her (makes her drop tools).
short_description: Unrailed! is a co-op multiplayer game where you have to work together with your friends to build a train track across endless procedurally generated worlds. Master random encounters with its inhabitants, upgrade your train and keep it from derailing!

name: Football Manager 2017
reviews:
Classic Best FM game!! Football Manager 2017 stands out as a deeply immersive and intricately detailed sports management simulation, offering a level of depth and realism that few games in the genre can match. From the moment you take charge of your chosen football club, whether a humble lower-division team or a global powerhouse, the game throws you into a complex web of decisions that affect every aspect of your club's success. The interface is packed with information â€” from player stats and training schedules to financial reports and scouting networks â€” demanding attention and strategic thinking at every turn.

One of Football Manager 2017â€™s greatest strengths lies in its expansive database, which includes tens of thousands of real-world players, staff, and teams from leagues all over the globe. This rich data set fuels the gameâ€™s simulation engine, creating authentic match outcomes and player performances that reflect real-life dynamics like form, morale, and fitness. The scouting system is particularly robust, allowing managers to search for talent tailored to their tactical approach, budget, and squad needs. Balancing transfer dealings, contract negotiations, and youth development requires patience and savvy, making each signing feel consequential.

The tactical side of the game is where Football Manager 2017 truly shines. Its match engine gives players unprecedented control over formations, playing styles, and in-game instructions. You can set team mentality, assign roles such as playmakers or target men, and tweak individual player instructions to craft a unique style of play. Watching the live match simulation unfold reveals the tangible effects of these choices, rewarding managers who study their teamâ€™s strengths and weaknesses and adapt accordingly. This depth ensures that no two seasons feel the same, as evolving tactics and opposition strategies constantly challenge your managerial skills.

Managing a football club in FM17 isnâ€™t just about tactics and transfers, though; the game also delves deeply into off-pitch matters. Media interactions, player personalities, and board expectations add layers of realism that force you to juggle relationships alongside performance. Handling press conferences with thoughtful or diplomatic responses can influence morale and public perception, while dealing with dressing room conflicts tests your leadership. The financial management system further adds to the challenge, requiring careful budgeting to avoid debt while investing in infrastructure and player development.

While Football Manager 2017 offers immense depth, it can be overwhelming for newcomers. The sheer volume of information and menus may initially feel daunting, and progress sometimes requires a steep learning curve. However, the game provides helpful tutorials and customizable difficulty settings that ease players into the experience. Veteran fans will appreciate subtle improvements over previous iterations, including better match animations, enhanced scouting reports, and more nuanced player interactions, all of which contribute to a richer simulation.

In summary, Football Manager 2017 delivers one of the most comprehensive and authentic football management experiences available on PC. Its attention to detail, realistic simulation, and strategic complexity make it a rewarding challenge for both casual fans and hardcore enthusiasts. Whether you dream of leading an underdog club to glory or maintaining dominance at the highest level, FM17 offers the tools and freedom to craft your own legacy in the beautiful game.

Rating: 6/10
short_description: Take control of your favourite football team in Football Manager 2017, the most realistic and immersive football management game to date. Itâ€™s the closest thing to doing the job for real!

name: Saving Grace
reviews: Enjoyable indie horror game. Excellent game if you like the horror genre. Quite a nice little horror game with afew hours of playtime, I enjoyed it and was spooky! Reminds me a little bit of doom towards the end
short_description: A first-person horror game revolving around the abduction of your daughter Grace. Cultists needs a sacrifice to resurrect the devil. Play as the father. Explore the past, present and future of this terrifying interactive story. Grace is counting on you.

name: Resident Evil
reviews:
I've only beat one of the two possible playthroughs, but wow this was a very new experience for me. Seriously feels like a real achievement to have beat this game 23 years later (29 for the original release). It's frustrating at times, but you get used to it. 

Some advice for new players. Play first as Jill. She has more inventory space than Chris, has the lockpick, and Barry as a partner who is very useful at times. Conserve Ink Ribbons reasonably, and look up what the questions at the beginning of the game mean for difficulty if that concerns you. gg crimsonheads r scarier than lickers
short_description: The game that defined the survival-horror genre is back! Check out the remastered HD version of Resident Evil.

genres: Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
name: KARDS - The WW2 Card Game
reviews: Great Game This game could be great if it was not focused on being so money hungry This game should be subtitled "Just google game-breaking unbeatable decks"
short_description: KARDS, The World War II Card Game, combines traditional CCG gameplay with innovative mechanics inspired by classic strategy games and real battlefield tactics. Take command and challenge other players in grand-scale warfare on the ground, air, or seas.

name: Killing Floor
reviews: Me favourite zombie wave co-op shooter. It's the best Killing Floor game in my opinion, love the vibe and the gameplay is satisfying but can be oh so hard. Sad that the sequels were blunders. Very entertaining zombie horde shooter and it nails the immersive horror experience. It's like a darker Left for Dead. As the original title in the Killing Floor series, it excels in weapon handling, combat feedback, immersive experience, and environmental atmosphere. Although the graphics appear somewhat outdated, it remains well worth playing.
short_description: 6-player co-op survival horror at its finest! Free updates, free special events and a ridiculous amount of fun!

name: Total War: THREE KINGDOMS
reviews:
The only total war game that I can play for hours.

That said it's kind of required to play for hours.

Holy shit am I still on my first campaign?? gg this game need to be balanced. complete waste of time
short_description: Total War: THREE KINGDOMS is the first in the award-winning series to recreate epic conflict across ancient China. Combining a gripping turn-based campaign of empire-building & conquest with stunning real-time battles, THREE KINGDOMS redefines the series in an age of heroes & legends.

name: Eador. Masters of the Broken World
reviews:
Eador has a lot of interesting ideas and, on paper, the potential to be a great game. Unfortunately, itâ€™s held back by painfully slow pacing and a serious lack of variety over time. Despite clearly taking inspiration from Heroes of Might and Magic, it ends up being far less fun to actually play. To start with the positives hero progression is genuinely well done. There are effectively twelve hero classes. The three base types mage, warrior, and scout can either stay pure at level 10 or branch into one of three subclasses, including hybrid options with their own unique abilities unlocked at levels 10 and 20. This system gives heroes a strong sense of identity and long-term progression. Exploration is another strong point. Heroes donâ€™t just conquer provinces or fight enemy heroes; they can also explore controlled provinces, uncovering locations filled with neutral creatures and warbands. These encounters reward experience, loot, and treasure, and thereâ€™s a decent variety of creatures and both magical and non-magical items to find. Unit variety is also respectable on the surface. You can recruit many different unit types, including non-human ones through quests and racial alliances. On top of that, spells allow you to raise undead, summon demons, or create magical constructs like golems and gargoyles, which helps keep army composition interesting early on.

Unfortunately, all of this is dragged down by how slow the game is. Neutral creatures scale aggressively the farther you move from your capital, forcing you to grind hero levels, equipment, and units for a long time before you can even reach enemy heroes and theyâ€™re just as stuck doing the same thing. Progress feels gated behind excessive preparation rather than meaningful challenge. Building progression is another major issue. Structures are extremely expensive, require too many prerequisite buildings, and escalate in cost dramatically. Reaching tier-three buildings often takes over 100 turns, while top-tier buildings can take several hundred. This turns empire development into a long, tedious waiting game.

Province guards are where things really fall apart. In theory, theyâ€™re a solid idea cheap defensive units ranging from basic militia to elite forces. In practice, theyâ€™re wildly unbalanced. Both the player and the AI can recruit absurdly strong province guards for a fraction of the cost of maintaining a comparable army. By the time you reach larger maps, the remaining AI players often have massively overpowered guards protecting their capitals. Defeating them usually requires top-tier units and high-level mage guilds, which again means hundreds of turns of grinding. If you enjoy slow buildup, it somehow gets even worse. Letting the AI grow stronger just results in province guards being stacked in every single province, turning the late game into a slog of repetitive, uninteresting battles. Fighting neutrals and guards over and over is far less engaging than fighting enemy armies, and the pace becomes mind-numbing.

Variety is another major disappointment. While the AI â€œmastersâ€ are thematically diverse undead lords, demigods, demon rulers, dragons, and more they all play almost identically. Every master recruits the same units, uses the same spells, and relies mostly on human troops. Demon lords rarely field demons, undead masters barely summon undead, and even good-aligned masters happily use evil province guards and summon demons. Aside from the occasional â€œArmy of Chaos,â€ the flavor feels entirely cosmetic. When a demon master threatens you with a demonic invasion and shows up with a human army identical to yours, it completely kills the atmosphere.

 fun So first time playing and right after you set up your base and it explains all your neighbors are independent it states now attack them! Just attack your peaceful neighbors.
short_description: Eador is a universe made of countless shards of land drifting in the Great Nothing. Each of the shards is a little world unto itself, with geography and denizens of its own. The power over the shards is bitterly contested by Masters, the immortal beings mortals believe to be gods.

name: Mirror's Edgeâ„¢
reviews:
forgot how to run off a wall gg Mirror's Edge is quite the missed opportunity. The concept is good: free-flowing parkour across the rooftops of a near-future city. There are some things which they managed to achieve which are frankly amazing for 2008. The visuals are still impressive for its age, featuring global illumination and the PhysX system in ways that put many modern titles to shame. I canâ€™t recall another game that simulates bullets ripping through cloth quite like Mirrorâ€™s Edge does.

That said, the game has numerous issues that ultimately spoiled my playthrough. The biggest problem is how linear it is; I wish there was more freedom to use the environment creatively when tackling levels. Nearly every chapter turns into an action set piece. While I donâ€™t mind the occasional gunfight, I would much rather focus on movement and traversal than being turned into a bullet sponge for helicopter gunners.

Unfortunately, combat is both frequent and poorly implemented. It feels clumsy and actively works against the gameâ€™s strengths. The story doesnâ€™t help either â€” itâ€™s very weak, with minimal world-building to support it. On a technical and design level, some of the lighting is far too intense; certain levels feel blindingly bright, almost like youâ€™ve arrived at the gates of heaven. There are also practical frustrations: alt-tabbing causes the game to crash, several sections are highly repetitive, and some levels are confusing enough that I had to consult a video guide due to unintuitive design.

As you can see, I found a lot of faults with this game but if you just want a solid parkour title to check out, I'm sure you will find some enjoyment here. Some of the environments are fantastic and there's one section in particular that I will remember for a long time. In the moments where Mirrorâ€™s Edge is firing on all cylinders â€” free of combat, clear in its direction, and focused on movement â€” itâ€™s pure bliss. Still the best parkour game
short_description: In a city where information is heavily monitored, couriers called Runners transport sensitive data. In this seemingly utopian paradise, a crime has been committed, & you are being hunted. You are a Runner called Faith and this innovative first-person action-adventure is your story.

name: Monaco: What's Yours Is Mine
reviews:
Monaco: Whatâ€™s Yours Is Mine is a clever, stylish, and often delightfully chaotic heist game that turns every mission into a miniature sandbox of stealth, improvisation, and teamwork. Developed by Pocketwatch Games and published by Humble Games, it presents itself with a deceptively simple top-down blueprint aesthetic, yet beneath that minimalist exterior lies one of the most inventive cooperative stealth experiences in indie gaming. The premise is straightforward â€” assemble a crew of thieves, infiltrate a target location, steal valuables, and escape â€” but the execution embraces unpredictability, player creativity, and dynamic problem-solving in ways that make every run feel like its own little story.

The game revolves around eight playable characters, each with a unique skillset that dramatically changes how a mission unfolds. The Cleaner can knock out guards silently, the Pickpocketâ€™s monkey companion collects loot from a safe distance, the Hacker disables electronics remotely, and the Mole can literally tunnel through walls. These abilities turn levels into intricate puzzles where multiple solutions are always possible. A carefully coordinated run might see one player disabling alarms while another sneaks through vents, but the beauty of Monaco is that plans rarely go perfectly. A mistimed step or careless noise can send guards swarming, transforming a quiet infiltration into a frenzied chase where players must improvise escape routes, dive into bushes, or sprint blindly toward the exit while alarms blare. The game embraces this chaos, allowing success through mastery or sheer panic, and both approaches can be equally fun.

Stealth in Monaco is refreshingly intuitive. Vision is restricted to what the characters can actually see, creating suspenseful blind spots as you navigate tight hallways or peer around corners. Guards patrol realistic patterns, and audio cues â€” footsteps, radios, alarms â€” become vital tools for planning your next move. The combination of line-of-sight, sound, and environmental hazards ensures that even simple rooms carry tension. When everything falls into place, the game captures the thrill of a perfectly executed heist. When it doesnâ€™t, it leans hilariously into the pandemonium that follows. This dual nature â€” tension and comedy intertwined â€” is one of the gameâ€™s most enduring charms.

Co-op elevates the experience to a whole new level. While Monaco can technically be played solo, it is clearly designed with multiplayer in mind. Working as a coordinated team of two to four players transforms each mission into a shared puzzle where each personâ€™s role matters. Communication becomes essential, whether youâ€™re calling out guard movements, coordinating distractions, or rushing in to revive a teammate who got cornered. Even when runs devolve into chaos, the resulting scramble often becomes the most memorable part of the session. Few games capture the feeling of a botched heist with as much humor and energy as Monaco, and it is in these moments of frantic improvisation that the game truly shines.

The blueprint-style art direction supports the gameplay with remarkable clarity. Rooms, furniture, doors, and guards are instantly readable, even amid the chaos of alarms and pursuit. The limited color palette and dynamic lighting help keep attention where it matters without cluttering the screen. The soundtrack, composed by Austin Wintory, adds flair with its energetic, jazz-infused rhythms that swell during chase sequences and lend a theatrical flair to each caper. Though simple at first glance, Monacoâ€™s audiovisual identity is tightly designed to reinforce the gameâ€™s fast pace and playful tone.

That said, Monaco is not without limitations. The campaignâ€™s structure is relatively linear, and once youâ€™ve mastered its missions, the core loop does not evolve significantly. There are no long-term progression systems, skill trees, or persistent upgrades â€” the appeal lies in mastering characters and perfecting heists rather than building a character over time. Players seeking narrative depth or a more traditional adventure may find the storytelling light and the campaign somewhat minimalistic. Additionally, while the gameâ€™s chaos is part of its charm, it can be frustrating when playing solo or with uncoordinated groups; some levels become disproportionately difficult without teamwork, and certain character abilities feel far more effective in co-op than on their own.

Despite these limitations, Monaco remains a standout in the co-op stealth genre. Its blend of emergent gameplay, distinct character roles, and fast-paced decision-making creates a unique rhythm that few games replicate. It thrives not on precision alone but on the unpredictable synergy that arises when players share a heist together â€” the whispered strategies, the sudden disasters, the daring rescues, and the breathless escapes. Whether youâ€™re sneaking through shadows or sprinting through open hallways with guards at your heels, Monaco captures the exhilaration of a heist gone right â€” or gloriously wrong.

For players who enjoy cooperative games, improvisational problem-solving, or stylish stealth with a comedic edge, Monaco: Whatâ€™s Yours Is Mine is an unforgettable experience. It is a game that rewards curiosity, creativity, and camaraderie, and even years after its release, it remains one of the most distinctly charming and replayable heist games on Steam.

Rating: 9/10 A classic co-op game. Still a blast to play with some friends. Genuinely the best heist game ever made.
short_description: Monaco: What's Yours Is Mine is a single player or co-op heist game. Assemble a crack team of thieves, case the joint, and pull off the perfect heist.

short_description: Uncertain of his sister's fate, a boy enters LIMBO

name: This War of Mine
reviews:
[h1] Yet another hyped-up game where everyone just blindly follows the crowd. [/h1]


[b] :TLDR: [/b]

Initially an interesting setup. But then it devolves into an extremely repetitive waiting simulator with almost no base progress and an unbelievably terrible UI.


[u] Pros: [/u]

- Good atmosphere

- Interesting setting that not only shows the consequences of war but also reflects your own actions within it.

- Your actions have consequences (e.g. if you loot a lot, others will do the same.)

--> That's essentially it for the advantages.


[u] Cons: [/u]

- I find the controls and UI insulting (only mouse, no WASD, no 1, 2, 3 to cycle through characters).

- Due to the game design, only one person in the group can loot, which is simply poorly designed and unrealistic, especially considering the game claims to be realistic.

- There's practically only one music track in the entire game, which is incredibly annoying and monotonous.

-/+ The atmosphere is good, but the graphics are poor, or rather, very basic for 2014.

- Very little progress in base building and incredibly tedious grinding.

- No character development.

- The characters are almost constantly sad about everythingâ€”it's war, after all... I mean.

- Battles feel clunky, and you're almost always outnumbered. There's nothing satisfying about them, since everything has to be done with the mouse.

+/- No Saves, but you leave the game. Might be ok in this setting, but frusttrates when testing things.


[b] Conclusion [/b]

I was simply bored and frustrated. I wanted to experience the ending, which was even more frustrating, disappointing, and empty. You get a few lines of text about the characters that only superficially rehash what was already known about their backstories. For example: A character dies: "Will his family visit his grave?" --> Wow! How profound and creative. -.- I mean, if I kill loads of people for loot and there are witnesses, it's not even mentioned in the end.

The game is just incredibly disappointing for me, and I don't understand the many positive reviews. It's probably just another hype train. I bought it on sale and was more than glad I did. This War of Mine is not a typical war game. Instead of action, it focuses on survival, moral choices, and the emotional weight of war. Every decision matters, and there are no easy answers. Managing resources, helping others, or choosing not to can change everything. Itâ€™s slow, heavy, and sometimes uncomfortable, but thatâ€™s exactly why itâ€™s so powerful. A must-play if you want a meaningful experience, not just entertainment. fun strat game
short_description: In This War Of Mine you do not play as an elite soldier, rather a group of civilians trying to survive in a besieged city; struggling with lack of food, medicine and constant danger from snipers and hostile scavengers. The game provides an experience of war seen from an entirely new angle.

name: Resident Evil 4
reviews:
Resident Evil 4 is pure brilliance.
From start to finish, I never felt bored for a single moment. The pacing is near perfect, constantly pushing you forward while still letting the atmosphere sink in.

The graphics are stunning, the physics feel incredibly polished, and the combat is satisfying in every encounter. Every weapon has weight, every enemy feels dangerous, and every area is crafted with care. The cutscenes are cinematic without overstaying their welcome and blend smoothly into gameplay.

Itâ€™s one of those rare games where everything just clicksâ€”gameplay, visuals, tension, and fun. A masterclass in action-horror and easily one of the best experiences Iâ€™ve had. Short and sweet and simple.

In parts better than the OG, in other parts not so much. 

The third act is far better as is the castle design and features, but I did enjoy the village and its surroundings in the OG RE4 better.

Probably the best "remaster" I've ever played, though. The most replayable survival horror made yet
short_description: Survival is just the beginning. Six years have passed since the biological disaster in Raccoon City. Leon S. Kennedy, one of the survivors, tracks the president's kidnapped daughter to a secluded European village, where there is something terribly wrong with the locals.

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Early Access
name: Path of Exile 2
reviews: Game freezes often. Loading times into zones were almost instant last season. This season they're anywhere from 20 seconds, to 5 minutes...absolutely unplayable. Had no issues 2 weeks ago playing on previous season. Tried rolling back drivers, changing from dx12 to dx11, and even vulkan. No change. There is no reason to be playing this over Diablo 4 currently. For sure the best ARPG on the market
short_description: Path of Exile 2 is a next generation Action RPG from Grinding Gear Games, featuring co-op for up to six players. Set years after the original Path of Exile, you will return to the dark world of Wraeclast and seek to end the corruption that is spreading.

name: The Long Dark
reviews:
Ive been playing this since Early Access on Xbox a decade ago. Just picked it up on Steam, and its looks amazing on my Deck's OLED screen. I love this game because no one is talking to me or telling me to fetch stuff for them. Its just hiking, hunting, and fishing. Incredible experience, and undoubtedly my favorite survival sim of all time. The concept of "you will die, it's only a matter of when and how" is unparalleled within the genre; like the best im-sims, the organic survival scenarios that compound and morph and materialize into singular brilliant moments and experiences are vast and epic.

Imagine...

You're slowly freezing to death, being hunted by predators, starving, exhausted, and praying for shelter while in the midst of a blizzard that lowers your visibility to practically zero. You can sense the danger getting closer, your legs getting more tired, your energy being zapped, the cold setting in, and your inevitable death becoming more and more certain. And then.. eureka!! You stumble into a small hamlet of a town, a few houses, respite, clarity. Maybe the old church will have the medicines you need, maybe the boathouse has one or two bullets for the pistol you found earlier in that abandoned car. There are materials to break down, but how much energy can you extoll right now? Is it worth it? Luckily, there was a box of quality tinder to build a fire with and make some tea and cook some food. But your energy is still low, and supplies are dwindling. How long can you wait? Can you outlast the blizzard? Is it worth it to leave now? You can't stay there forever...

Fantastic, truly. This is a must play. very beautiful lower diffs get way too easy after a while. but overall one of my top 3 games.
short_description: THE LONG DARK is a thoughtful, exploration-survival experience that challenges solo players to think for themselves as they explore an expansive frozen wilderness in the aftermath of a geomagnetic disaster. There are no zombies -- only you, the cold, and all the threats Mother Nature can muster.
